Award.AwardTitle: Structured Composite Materials with Variable Adhesion Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal 1435745
Structured Composite Materials with Variable Adhesion Properties

There are a number of applications for materials that have the ability to adhere strongly to a surface under certain circumstances, and to exhibit weak adhesion in other circumstances. Materials with variable adhesion are needed for applications such as integrated circuit fabrication, solar cell manufacturing, medical tapes, and climbing robots. While adhesion at an interface can be altered through external forces such as temperature or magnetic field, a much simpler design is to design materials with variable adhesion that can be altered depending on the direction of the applied force. This award supports fundamental research that will enable the design and fabrication of structured composite materials that offer the ability to significantly vary adhesion by changing the direction of loading applied to the adhered interface. These composite materials with variable adhesion have uses in manufacturing, healthcare, and consumer products, thus this research will benefit U.S. industry and the economy. This award will also result in the training of students in several disciplines, including mechanical engineering, microfabrication, polymer processing, and materials science. This training in key engineering areas will help to enhance the technical workforce and improve U.S. competiveness.

The proposed composite materials provide the ability to significantly alter the effective adhesion of an interface by changing the loading direction. While the basic principles of these materials have been demonstrated through preliminary experiments and modeling, fundamental research is needed to establish an understanding of the relationship between the processing, structure, and adhesion properties of structured composite materials. This research will use analytical and computational mechanics models to investigate the relationship between the structure of the composite and the failure behavior of the interface. Experiments will be performed to characterize the adhesive and constitutive properties of the constituent materials of the composites as input for the models. A combination of microfabrication and polymer molding techniques will be used to fabricate structured composite materials that will then be extensively characterized under various loading conditions. The combination of modeling and experiments in this research will lead to new fundamental understanding of structured composite materials and will enable the rational design of materials with variable adhesion.

Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated a new approach to create surfaces with reversible and tunable adhesion that can be used to controllably adhere to a diverse range of objects.  Surfaces with reversible and tunable adhesion have applications such as robotic gripping, pick-and-place manufacturing processes, and robots that climb and perch.  Previous work to develop such surfaces has largely focused on bioinspired surfaces comprised of many fibrils with complex geometries. In this project, a different approach based on composite fibrils and structures was pursued.  The composites are composed of a soft material and stiff material and the geometry and placement of the stiff component is engineered to achieve the desired behavior of the surface. With appropriate design, these structured composite materials can achieve high-strength adhesion that can also be reduced to facilitate detachment by applying force in specific directions.

The outcomes of this project include an understanding of the mechanics of structured composite surfaces, techniques to manufacture the surfaces, experimental measurements of performance, and application of the surfaces in a semiconductor manufacturing process.  Computational models were used to investigate the adhesion mechanics of the surfaces and the understanding developed enables design of structured composite surfaces with specific adhesion properties.  Structured composite surfaces with various geometries were fabricated via polymer-based manufacturing and microfabrication processes and their performance was characterized.  The experiments showed that the adhesives have high strength, but also can be detached easily when the loading direction is altered.  The experiments validated the models and showed that the overall level and tunability of the adhesion can be prescribed through design. The utility of microscale composite pillars with tunable adhesion was demonstrated by using them as a stamp in microtransfer printing, a semiconductor manufacturing process that allows for pick-and-place assembly of ultra-thin microelectronic, micromechanical, and LED components.  The composite pillars provided high retrieval forces for picking up components and allowed the components to subsequently be placed (i.e. ?printed?) by exploiting their low adhesion state. The intellectual merit of this project lies in the understanding and advances in mechanics, materials, and manufacturing highlighted above.

The technical broader impacts of this work lie in the new robotic and manufacturing systems that these surfaces will enable. Surfaces with strong and robust tunable adhesion offer new ways for automated systems to interact with objects and the environment and, for example, allow for the design of simpler and more efficient gripping and handling systems.  New materials, such as structured composite surfaces, are crucial for enabling new functions in robotic systems.  The broader impacts from an education and outreach perspective include the training of graduate and undergraduate students as well as public outreach.  Multiple engineering students, at various levels, performed research on this project and advanced their knowledge of materials, mechanics, and manufacturing.  This training and research provided them with crucial experience that they will leverage as members of the technical work force in the United States.  Finally, the research team developed and implemented education and outreach activities to educate the public and K-12 students on the basic concepts of engineering sticky materials.

Modified by: Kevin T Turner

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project investigated a new approach to create surfaces with reversible and tunable adhesion that can be used to controllably adhere to a diverse range of objects. Surfaces with reversible and tunable adhesion have applications such as robotic gripping, pick-and-place manufacturing processes, and robots that climb and perch. Previous work to develop such surfaces has largely focused on bioinspired surfaces comprised of many fibrils with complex geometries. In this project, a different approach based on composite fibrils and structures was pursued. The composites are composed of a soft material and stiff material and the geometry and placement of the stiff component is engineered to achieve the desired behavior of the surface. With appropriate design, these structured composite materials can achieve high-strength adhesion that can also be reduced to facilitate detachment by applying force in specific directions. The outcomes of this project include an understanding of the mechanics of structured composite surfaces, techniques to manufacture the surfaces, experimental measurements of performance, and application of the surfaces in a semiconductor manufacturing process. Computational models were used to investigate the adhesion mechanics of the surfaces and the understanding developed enables design of structured composite surfaces with specific adhesion properties. Structured composite surfaces with various geometries were fabricated via polymer-based manufacturing and microfabrication processes and their performance was characterized. The experiments showed that the adhesives have high strength, but also can be detached easily when the loading direction is altered. The experiments validated the models and showed that the overall level and tunability of the adhesion can be prescribed through design. The utility of microscale composite pillars with tunable adhesion was demonstrated by using them as a stamp in microtransfer printing, a semiconductor manufacturing process that allows for pick-and-place assembly of ultra-thin microelectronic, micromechanical, and LED components. The composite pillars provided high retrieval forces for picking up components and allowed the components to subsequently be placed (i.e. ?printed?) by exploiting their low adhesion state. The intellectual merit of this project lies in the understanding and advances in mechanics, materials, and manufacturing highlighted above. The technical broader impacts of this work lie in the new robotic and manufacturing systems that these surfaces will enable. Surfaces with strong and robust tunable adhesion offer new ways for automated systems to interact with objects and the environment and, for example, allow for the design of simpler and more efficient gripping and handling systems. New materials, such as structured composite surfaces, are crucial for enabling new functions in robotic systems. The broader impacts from an education and outreach perspective include the training of graduate and undergraduate students as well as public outreach. Multiple engineering students, at various levels, performed research on this project and advanced their knowledge of materials, mechanics, and manufacturing. This training and research provided them with crucial experience that they will leverage as members of the technical work force in the United States. Finally, the research team developed and implemented education and outreach activities to educate the public and K-12 students on the basic concepts of engineering sticky materials.
